prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; What is the Type of Consideration
expected completion:
The Agreement provides for a purely cash‐based consideration.  Specifically:  

1. Offer Price (WHEREAS clause)  
   - Parent’s Merger Subsidiary will “commence a tender offer … to purchase … all of the shares … at a price per share of $22.00 … in cash, without interest.”  

2. Merger Consideration (Section (a))  
   - “Each Share outstanding immediately prior to the Effective Time … shall be canceled and converted into the right to receive the Offer Price in cash, without interest (the ‘Merger Consideration’).”  

Accordingly, the Type of Consideration under the Acquisition Agreement is cash consideration of $22.00 per share.
source_file: maud/The Michaels Companies, Inc._Apollo Global Management, LLC.txt

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; What about the Fiduciary exception to the No-Shop Clause
expected completion:
Below is what Section 6.03(d) (the “fiduciary exception”) says about the interplay between the Company’s fiduciary duties and the No‑Shop covenant:  

1. Location of the Exception  
   • Found in Section 6.03(d) of the Acquisition Agreement (“Go‑Shop; No Solicitation”).  

2. Triggering Conditions  
   • Prior to the Acceptance Time, the Company (or its Representatives) must receive a written Acquisition Proposal from a third party.  
   • The Company Board, after consulting its financial advisor and outside legal counsel, must determine that the proposal “is, could lead to, result in or constitute a Superior Proposal.”  

3. Permitted Activities  
   Once the Board makes the determination above, the Company may:  
   (i)   Engage in negotiations or discussions with the third party and its Representatives; and  
   (ii)  Furnish non‑public information about the Company or its Subsidiaries to that third party (subject to an “Acceptable Confidentiality Agreement”).  

4. Conditions on Information Sharing  
   • Before or substantially concurrently with sharing any material non‑public information with the third party, the Company must furnish that same information to Parent (if not already provided).  
   • The Company may not provide any of Parent’s or Merger Subsidiary’s non‑public information to the third party.  

5. Cut‑Off Date Exception  
   After the Cut‑Off Date and notwithstanding the No‑Shop Period Start Date, the Company may continue to engage with “Excluded Parties” under the same exceptions described in Section 6.03(a), without being bound by Sections 6.03(b) and 6.03(c), until the Cut‑Off Date.  

Cited Provision  
“Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in Section 6.03, if at any time prior to the Acceptance Time … the Company Board determines … [it is a] Superior Proposal, then the Company … may (i) engage … in negotiations … and (ii) furnish … non‑public information … provided, that (A) … make available to Parent any material non‑public information … and (B) not provide … any non‑public information of or relating to Parent …” (Section 6.03(d)).  

No other “fiduciary out” or broader exception appears in the provided context.
source_file: maud/The Michaels Companies, Inc._Apollo Global Management, LLC.txt

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; What is the Definition of "Superior Proposal"
expected completion:
Below is the defining language of “Superior Proposal” as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement (emphasis added):  

“Superior Proposal” means a bona fide written Acquisition Proposal for at least a majority of the outstanding Shares or at least a majority of the consolidated assets of the Company and its Subsidiaries that  
  1. was not solicited in material breach by the Company of the first sentence of Section 6.03(b) or the first sentence of Section 6.03(c), and  
  2. the Company Board determines in good faith, after consultation with its financial advisor and outside legal counsel, and taking into account all relevant terms and conditions of such Acquisition Proposal, is more favorable to the Company’s stockholders from a financial point of view than the Merger (taking into account any irrevocable written proposal by Parent to amend the terms of this Agreement pursuant to Section 6.03(h)).  

(Source: Acquisition Agreement, Definition of “Superior Proposal”)
source_file: maud/The Michaels Companies, Inc._Apollo Global Management, LLC.txt

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; Information about the Fiduciary Termination Right Triggers for termination
expected completion:
The Agreement’s sole “fiduciary‐out” (i.e., Company‐initiated) termination right is set forth in Section 10.01(d)(i).  In brief, the trigger is:  

1.  Prior to the Acceptance Time, the Company Board:  
    •  Authorizes the Company to enter into a definitive agreement concerning a Superior Proposal (as defined and governed by Section 6.03(h)); and  
    •  The Company contemporaneously enters into that definitive agreement; and  

2.  The Company pays the Company Termination Fee required under Section 11.05(a)(ii).  

Citations:  
–  Section 10.01(d)(i) (fiduciary termination right)  
–  Section 6.03(h) (definition/governance of “Superior Proposal”)  
–  Section 11.05(a)(ii) (Company Termination Fee)

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; Is there a Tail provision for acquisition proposals
expected completion:
Based solely on the language of Section 11.05 of the provided Agreement, there is a “tail” provision for Acquisition Proposals:

1. Tail Period  
   – Section 11.05(a)(iii)(C) provides that if this Agreement is terminated and, within nine (9) months thereafter, the Company (The Michaels Companies, Inc.) both:  
     a. enters into a definitive agreement for an Acquisition Proposal; and  
     b. thereafter consummates that Acquisition Proposal,  
   then the Company must pay the full Company Termination Fee to Parent (Magic AcquireCo, Inc.) on the date of such consummation.

2. Citation  
   – See Section 11.05(a)(iii)(C).

No other tail period or differing mechanism appears in the text you provided.

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "Magic AcquireCo, Inc." and Target "The Michaels Companies, Inc."; What are the Ordinary course of business covenants
expected completion:
Below is a summary of the “ordinary course of business” covenants imposed on the Company (The Michaels Companies, Inc.) from the date of the Acquisition Agreement until the earlier of the Effective Time or termination of the Agreement (all citations are to Section 6.01 of the Agreement):

1. General Covenant  
   1.1. The Company (and each of its Subsidiaries) shall conduct its business in the ordinary course, taken as a whole, materially consistent with past practice, except:  
        • for matters set forth in Section 6.01 of the Company Disclosure Letter;  
        • actions taken under Section 8.07(h);  
        • actions required by Applicable Law or Contract;  
        • actions due to factors excluded from the definition of Material Adverse Effect; or  
        • actions taken with Parent’s prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed; deemed given if Parent does not object in writing within five Business Days of a written request) (Section 6.01).

2. Specific “Best Efforts” Covenants  
   From the date hereof until closing, the Company shall use its reasonable best efforts to:  
   2.1. Preserve intact its present business organization (Section 6.01(I)(x));  
   2.2. Keep available the services of its directors, officers and key employees (Section 6.01(I)(y)); and  
   2.3. Maintain existing relationships with its material suppliers and other persons having material business relationships with it (Section 6.01(I)(z)).

3. Definition of “Ordinary Course”  
   References to “ordinary course” or “ordinary course of business” mean the conduct of the Company and its Subsidiaries, taken as a whole, in a manner:  
   • Materially consistent with past practice; and  
   • Except for Section 6.01(II), including reasonable good-faith actions or omissions in response to COVID-19 or COVID-19 Measures (Section 6.01, second paragraph).

No additional “ordinary course” covenants are stated in the provided excerpt.
source_file: maud/The Michaels Companies, Inc._Apollo Global Management, LLC.txt

expected completion:

• Section 7.3(a) (No Solicitation) – prohibits the Company, its Subsidiaries, directors, officers, controlled Affiliates and other Representatives from, among other things, soliciting, initiating or encouraging any Acquisition Proposal or discussions that could lead to one, and requires the Company to terminate and return or destroy confidential information previously provided to any third party (other than Parent).

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "LVMH Moët Hennessy-Louis Vuitton SE" and Target "Tiffany & Co."; What is the Definition of "Superior Proposal"
expected completion:
Below is the definition of “Superior Proposal” as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement between LVMH Moët Hennessy‑Louis Vuitton SE (“Parent”) and Tiffany & Co. (“Company”):

“Superior Proposal” means all of the following (quoted and numbered for clarity):

1.   An unsolicited, bona fide written Acquisition Proposal  
     – With all references to fifteen percent (15%) in the definition of “Acquisition Proposal” deemed to reference eighty and 1/10th percent (80.1%).  

2.   The Company Board has determined in good faith (after consultation with a financial advisor of nationally recognized reputation and outside legal counsel), taking into account all financial, legal, regulatory and other aspects of:  
     a.   The Acquisition Proposal itself, and  
     b.   This Agreement,  

3.   Such Acquisition Proposal is reasonably likely to be consummated in accordance with its terms.

4.   Such Acquisition Proposal would result in a transaction more favorable to the stockholders of the Company (solely in their capacities as such) from a financial point of view than the transaction contemplated by this Agreement (after taking into account any revisions to the terms of this Agreement proposed by Parent pursuant to Section 7.3(d)(ii)).

5.   Such Acquisition Proposal was not obtained or made as a direct or indirect result of a breach of Section 7.3.

Source: Quoted from the provided “Acquisition Proposal” and “Superior Proposal” definitions.

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "LVMH Moët Hennessy-Louis Vuitton SE" and Target "Tiffany & Co."; What is the Definition of "Interveining Event"
expected completion:
Below is the Definition of “Intervening Event” as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement between Parent (LVMH Moët Hennessy‑Louis Vuitton SE) and Target (Tiffany & Co.).  

“Intervening Event” means any event, occurrence, fact, condition, change, development, circumstance or effect or cause thereof (“Effect”) occurring or arising after the date of this Agreement that is material to the Company and its Subsidiaries, taken as a whole, and that satisfies both of the following:  

1.  Knowledge and Foreseeability  
    a.  It was not known to, or reasonably foreseeable by, the Company Board as of or prior to the execution of this Agreement (or, if known or reasonably foreseeable, its material consequences were not known or reasonably foreseeable by the Company Board), and  
    b.  It (or any material consequence thereof) becomes known to, or reasonably foreseeable by, the Company Board prior to the time the Requisite Company Vote is obtained.  

2.  Exclusions  
    The event, and any consequence thereof, must not in any way involve or relate to:  
    i.   An Acquisition Proposal;  
    ii.  Any changes in the market price or trading volume of the Company or Parent or of the major U.S. stock indexes;  
    iii. Any changes in the Company’s credit ratings;  
    iv.  The Company or Parent meeting, failing to meet or exceeding published or unpublished revenue or market‑consensus earnings projections (in and of itself); or  
    v.   Any changes or conditions generally affecting the economies or the industries in which the Company and its Subsidiaries operate—except to the extent such Effect has a materially disproportionate effect on the Company and its Subsidiaries, taken as a whole, relative to others in those industries.  

It is understood that, with respect to clauses (i) through (iv), the underlying Effect giving rise to or contributing to any such change or event may be considered when determining whether an Intervening Event has occurred, to the extent not otherwise excluded.  

Source: Acquisition Agreement, Definition of “Intervening Event.”

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "LVMH Moët Hennessy-Louis Vuitton SE" and Target "Tiffany & Co."; Information about the Fiduciary Termination Right Triggers for termination
expected completion:
Below is what the Agreement (as provided) says about the Company’s “fiduciary-out” termination right.  

1.   Trigger (Section 9.3(b))  
     –  “Prior to the time the Requisite Company Vote is obtained,” the Company may terminate this Agreement  
     –  Purpose: “to enter into an Alternative Acquisition Agreement”  

2.   Conditions for valid termination  
     a.  Compliance with Section 7.3(d)(ii)  
         •  (This is the “fiduciary out” clause—i.e., the board may pursue a Superior Proposal consistent with its duties, provided it follows the procedural requirements set forth in Section 7.3(d)(ii).)  
     b.  Payment of the Company Termination Fee  
         •  Must be paid “prior to or concurrently with such termination” in accordance with Section 9.5(b)  

3.   Missing information  
     –  Full text of Section 7.3(d)(ii) (defining the board’s procedural steps when considering a Superior or Alternative Proposal)  
     –  Full text of Section 9.5(b) (detailing the amount and mechanics of the Company Termination Fee)  

Without Sections 7.3(d)(ii) and 9.5(b), we cannot state further conditions, timelines or fee amounts.

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "LVMH Moët Hennessy-Louis Vuitton SE" and Target "Tiffany & Co."; Is there a Tail provision for acquisition proposals
expected completion:
Based solely on Section 9.5 of the provided context, there is a “tail” provision governing third-party acquisition proposals.  In particular:

1. Section 9.5(b) creates a 12-month “tail” following termination, during which a third-party Acquisition Proposal will trigger the Company Termination Fee if it is consummated in an Alternative Acquisition Agreement:  
   • Section 9.5(b)(i)(A) requires that a third party must have made or publicly announced an Acquisition Proposal, and  
   • Section 9.5(b)(i)(B) requires that, within twelve (12) months after termination, the Company enters into an Alternative Acquisition Agreement with respect to that proposal (with a 50% stock-ownership threshold substituted for the usual 15%).  

2. If both (A) and (B) occur, then “immediately prior to or concurrently with” the entry into the Alternative Acquisition Agreement, the Company must pay the $575 million Company Termination Fee.  

No other “tail” beyond this twelve-month post-termination period is expressly provided in Section 9.5.

prompt: Consider the Acquisition Agreement between Parent "LVMH Moët Hennessy-Louis Vuitton SE" and Target "Tiffany & Co."; What are the Ordinary course of business covenants
expected completion:
Below is a summary of the “ordinary course of business” covenants as set forth in the provided excerpts from the Acquisition Agreement between Parent (LVMH) and the Company (Tiffany & Co.).  All citations refer to the numbering in your context.

1. Definition of “Ordinary Course of Business”  
   – “Ordinary Course of Business” means the conduct of the relevant business in the ordinary course, which for the Company (Tiffany) and its Subsidiaries:  
     • Includes, without limitation, the manner in which they have been operating from the Original Signing Date through the date of the Agreement.  
     • Includes any COVID-19 Measures taken by the Company or its Subsidiaries after the date of the Agreement.  
   (Definition immediately preceding Section 7.1)

2. Covenants in Section 7.1(a) – Conduct of the Company  
   From execution of the Agreement until the earlier of the Effective Time or termination under Article IX, the Company shall, and shall cause each Subsidiary to, except as expressly permitted below:  
   a. Comply in all material respects with:  
      i.   All applicable Laws; and  
      ii.  The material requirements of all Company Material Contracts; and  
   b. Conduct its business in all material respects in the Ordinary Course of Business.  
   (Section 7.1(a)(1))

3. Permitted Deviations from Ordinary Course  
   The foregoing covenant does not prohibit the Company or its Subsidiaries from taking actions that are:  
   a. Specifically set forth in Section 7.1(a)(i)–(xxiv) of the Company Disclosure Letter;  
   b. Consented to in writing by Parent (such consent not to be unreasonably conditioned, withheld, or delayed, and to be provided as set forth in Section 7.2);  
   c. Previously approved in writing by Parent under the Original Merger Agreement;  
   d. Taken in compliance with a Company Material Contract;  
   e. Specifically contemplated by the Agreement;  
   f. Required by a Governmental Entity or applicable Law; or  
   g. COVID-19 Measures.  
   (Section 7.1(a), introductory clause and clauses (A)–(C))

4. Missing Information  
   – The contents of Section 7.1(a)(i)–(xxiv) of the Company Disclosure Letter are not provided, so the specific permitted non-ordinary-course actions thereunder are unknown.  
   – Section 7.2 (governing timing and manner of Parent’s consent) is also not included.

Summary  
Under Section 7.1(a) and the defined term “Ordinary Course of Business,” Tiffany & Co. is required to maintain its historical operational practices and, except for certain narrow exceptions (including specified disclosure-letter items, Parent consent, legal requirements, COVID-19 measures, etc.), to (i) comply materially with applicable law and material contracts and (ii) conduct its business materially in the ordinary course from signing until the merger closes (or the agreement terminates).

   • If within twelve (12) months after that termination the Company (i) enters into a definitive agreement to consummate any such Acquisition Proposal, and (ii) that Proposal is ultimately consummated (regardless of whether consummation occurs within the 12-month window), then a fee becomes payable.  

3. Amount and Timing of Fee  
   • On the date of consummation of the Acquisition Proposal, the Company must pay the “Company Termination Fee” to Parent (or its designee).  
   • For purposes of this subsection only, the minimum “Acquisition Proposal” share-ownership threshold is raised from 15% to 50%.  

Citation:  
– Acquisition Agreement, Section 8.03(b)(i).

prompt: Consider the Merger Agreement between "Atlas CC Acquisition Corp." and "Cubic Corporation"; Where is the No-Shop Clause
expected completion:
The “no-shop” (i.e., no-solicitation) covenant is set forth in Section 5.03 of the Merger Agreement, entitled “Solicitation; Change of Company Recommendation.”  In particular:  

1. Section 5.03(a)(ii) contains the core “no-shop” restrictions, providing that, from the signing date until the earlier of the Effective Time or termination of the Agreement, the Company and its representatives will not, directly or indirectly, initiate, solicit, knowingly encourage or facilitate any Competing Proposal (clause (A)), furnish non-public information to a party making a Competing Proposal (clause (B)), engage in discussions or negotiations regarding a Competing Proposal (clause (C)), enter into any Alternative Acquisition Agreement (clause (D)), or agree to take any such prohibited actions (clause (E)).  

2. These prohibitions are subject only to the narrow carve-out in the proviso at the end of Section 5.03(a), which permits the Company to inform a third party making an inquiry that the Company is contractually prohibited from engaging with it.  

Because the Agreement does not label a separate “No-Shop” article, the functional no-shop obligations are embedded in Section 5.03(a)(ii)(A)–(E).

prompt: Consider the Merger Agreement between "Atlas CC Acquisition Corp." and "Cubic Corporation"; What about the Fiduciary exception to the No-Shop Clause
expected completion:
Below is what Section 5.03(b) of the Merger Agreement says about the “fiduciary exception” to the no-shop (non-solicitation) clause:

1.  General Rule  
    –  The Company is prohibited from soliciting or engaging with competing bidders (the “no-shop” obligation in Section 5.03(a)).

2.  Fiduciary Exception (Section 5.03(b))  
    –  Notwithstanding the no-shop obligation, if all of the following are true before the Company Stockholder Approval or termination:  
       a.  The Company receives a bona fide written “Competing Proposal” that was not solicited in breach of Section 5.03(a).  
       b.  The Company Board (or a committee) determines in good faith, after consulting its outside financial and legal advisors, that the Competing Proposal is—or would reasonably be expected to lead to—a “Superior Proposal.”  
       c.  The Board concludes that failing to engage with the bidder would likely violate the Board’s fiduciary duties under applicable law.  
    –  Then the Company (and its representatives) may:  
       •  Furnish information (subject first to an “Acceptable Confidentiality Agreement” if the bidder isn’t already bound), and  
       •  Participate in discussions or negotiations,  
      provided that any non-public information shared with the competing bidder is promptly (and in any event within 48 hours) also made available to Parent and Sub.

3.  Key Citations  
    –  Section 5.03(b)(i)–(ii): conditions triggering the exception.  
    –  Section 5.03(b)(A)–(B): actions permitted once those conditions are met.  
    –  Last sentence of Section 5.03(b): confidentiality‐and-notice requirements.

4.  No Other Exceptions Stated  
    –  The only carve-out to the no-shop clause in the provided text is this fiduciary exception.  
    –  If you need to know whether other carve-outs exist, the text provided is insufficient to answer.

prompt: Consider the Merger Agreement between "Atlas CC Acquisition Corp." and "Cubic Corporation"; What is the Definition of "Interveining Event"
expected completion:
Below is the definition of “Intervening Event” as set forth in the Merger Agreement between Atlas CC Acquisition Corp. and Cubic Corporation (quotation and organization verbatim from the provided context):

“Intervening Event” means a material Effect or state of facts that  
  1. was not known to, or reasonably foreseeable by, the Company Board prior to the execution of this Agreement, which Effect, or any material consequence thereof, becomes known to, or reasonably foreseeable by, the Company Board prior to the receipt of the Company Stockholder Approval and  
  2. does not relate to a Competing Proposal;  

provided, however, that an “Intervening Event” shall not include:  
  (i)  any Competing Proposal or other inquiry, offer or proposal that could lead to a Competing Proposal,  
  (ii) an Effect resulting from a breach of this Agreement by the Company or any of the Company Subsidiaries,  
  (iii) changes in the price of the Shares, in and of itself (provided, however, the underlying reasons for such changes may constitute an Intervening Event unless excluded by any other exclusion in this definition), or  
  (iv) the fact that, in and of itself, the Company exceeds any internal or published projections, estimates or expectations of the Company’s revenue, earnings or other financial performance or results of operations for any period (provided, however, the underlying reasons for such events may constitute an Intervening Event unless expressly excluded by any other exclusion in this definition).

1.   Section 7.01(d) (Company’s right to terminate before stockholder approval upon a Superior Proposal)  
     The Company may terminate this Agreement if all of the following occur prior to receipt of the Company Stockholder Approval:  
     a.  A “Superior Proposal” is received by the Company;  
         – See Section 7.01(d)(i).  
     b.  The Company Board (or a duly authorized committee) has authorized the Company, pursuant to Section 5.03(e), to enter into an Alternative Acquisition Agreement to consummate that Superior Proposal;  
         – See Section 7.01(d)(ii) and cross-referenced Section 5.03(e).  
     c.  The Company has fully complied with its obligations under Section 5.03 with respect to that Superior Proposal (other than any non-compliance that is both immaterial and unintentional);  
         – See Section 7.01(d)(iii).

If you require any other fiduciary-out triggers, they are not included in the excerpt you provided.

prompt: Consider the Merger Agreement between "Atlas CC Acquisition Corp." and "Cubic Corporation"; Is there a Tail provision for acquisition proposals
expected completion:
Based solely on the language of the provided Section 7.02 of the Merger Agreement, there is a “tail” provision covering acquisition (i.e., Competing) proposals.  In particular:

1. Tail Duration  
     – Paragraph 7.02(b)(i)(C) provides that the tail period is “concurrently with or within twelve (12) months after the date of any such termination.”  

2. Triggering Events  
   – If the Agreement is validly terminated (Section 7.02(b)(i)(A)) and, within that 12‑month tail period, either:  
     • the Company (or a subsidiary) enters into a definitive agreement to effect any Competing Proposal whose equity purchase price exceeds the agreed Aggregate Merger Consideration; or  
     • any Competing Proposal is consummated  
   – then the Company must pay the Company Termination Fee to Parent, on the timing set forth in Section 7.02(b)(i)(C)(1)–(2).

3. Payment Timing Depends on Counterparty  
   – If the new proposal is with the same person (or its affiliate) who made the prior proposal (Section 7.02(b)(i)(C)(1)), payment is due upon execution of the definitive agreement or consummation, whichever is earlier.  
   – If the counterparty is different, payment is due upon consummation (Section 7.02(b)(i)(C)(2)).

Citations:  
  • Tail period: Section 7.02(b)(i)(C)  
  • Triggering events and payment obligations: Section 7.02(b)(i)(A) & (C)
